column4: search for ttf in the repos, there are a number of them there.
stop that
so help me!!!
will you :)
I don't even know what your issue is, I just see you asking 'why'
well, I am facing huge problems here when I try to figure how is my HDD partioned.
or partitioned, is this a word?
What sort of problems?
well the guy just told me to mention I've used WIBI, which I am not 100% sure either but I think so if my memory can help me this time.
How did you install Ubuntu? Did you boot from the CD or did you start the install from Windows?
I have both Windows and Ubuntu installed at this HDD. And I am starting to feel both systems are HD space short.
if I remeber well I did start installation from Windows.
why is it so important ?
Because installing using WUBI does not partition the harddrive. It creates a file within Windows that it uses as a virtual drive.
ohh... and is it good ?
good? Many power users don't like it because it makes troubleshooting booting issues much harder to diagnose.
ok, and lets say I want to partition my disk now, without loosing Windows. But reinstalling Ubuntu on its free new partition, is it possible?
yes, but if you're having space issues in Windows, you should get those sorted out before continuing.
do you think if I partition the disk now from Linux side, can I loose Windows?
You should have backups before repartitioning.
I have it, how do I do that ?
with fdisk ?
use gparted from the Ubuntu live CD
But again, if you are having low diskspace issues right now, you need to figure those out before you continue.
